articles.headline: ‘It’s Horrendous’: The Heartache of a Migrant Boy Taken From His Father
articles.snippet: José, a 5-year-old from Honduras, cried himself to sleep when he first arrived at his foster parents’ house in Michigan. His father had been arrested and led away at the border.
articles.abstract: José, a 5-year-old from Honduras, cried himself to sleep when he first arrived at his foster parents’ house in Michigan. His father had been arrested and led away at the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he landed in Michigan in late May, all the weary little boy carried was a trash bag stuffed with dirty clothes from his dayslong trek across Mexico, and two small pieces of paper — one a stick-figure drawing of his family from Honduras, the other a sketch of his father, who had been arrested and led away after they arrived at the United States border in El Paso.

articles.headline: The Most Powerful Conservative Couple You’ve Never Heard Of
articles.snippet: Liz and Dick Uihlein, founders of the shipping supply giant Uline, have spent some $26 million this year alone, seeking to advance conservative causes anywhere they can.
articles.abstract: Liz and Dick Uihlein, founders of the shipping supply giant Uline, have spent some $26 million this year alone, seeking to advance conservative causes anywhere they can.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few political donors are as influential, yet little known, as Liz and Dick Uihlein.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Anger Flares as G-7 Heads to Quebec
articles.snippet: President Trump will skip most of the second day of the Group of 7 summit meeting with allies this weekend, the White House said late Thursday.
articles.abstract: President Trump will skip most of the second day of the Group of 7 summit meeting with allies this weekend, the White House said late Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will skip most of the second day of a summit meeting with allies this weekend, the White House said late Thursday, as he engaged in a contentious war of words over trade on the eve of a gathering that will underscore his isolation from the leaders of the world’s largest economies.

articles.headline: The Chemical Industry Scores a Big Win at the E.P.A.
articles.snippet: The agency has decided that it will not look at air, water or ground contaminants when it determines the health and safety risks of potentially toxic chemicals.
articles.abstract: The agency has decided that it will not look at air, water or ground contaminants when it determines the health and safety risks of potentially toxic chemicals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, after heavy lobbying by the chemical industry, is scaling back the way the federal government determines health and safety risks associated with the most dangerous chemicals on the market, documents from the Environmental Protection Agency show.

articles.headline: Why Trump Might Cave to China: Iowa Soybean Farmers
articles.snippet: Farmers are pressuring Congress for a compromise with China to avert a costly trade war. The Trump administration is showing signs of compromise.
articles.abstract: Farmers are pressuring Congress for a compromise with China to avert a costly trade war. The Trump administration is showing signs of compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all his bluster about trade wars, President Trump seems willing to push China only so far: Witness the deal on Thursday to grant Chinese telecom giant ZTE a reprieve from harsh American penalties. The reason is likely to lead straight to Iowa soybean and corn farmers like Benjamin Schmidt.

articles.headline: Maybe the Gig Economy Isn’t Reshaping Work After All
articles.snippet: Defying expectations, the first official survey of “alternative work arrangements” since 2005 shows that nontraditional employment has become less common.
articles.abstract: Defying expectations, the first official survey of “alternative work arrangements” since 2005 shows that nontraditional employment has become less common.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can see the gig economy everywhere but in the statistics.

articles.headline: Ex-Senate Aide Charged in Leak Case Where Times Reporter’s Records Were Seized
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors seized the records as part of an investigation into leaks of classified information to the news media by a former Senate aide.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors seized the records as part of an investigation into leaks of classified information to the news media by a former Senate aide.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Senate Intelligence Committee aide was arrested on Thursday in an investigation of classified information leaks where prosecutors also secretly seized years’ worth of a New York Times reporter’s phone and email records.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Nicholas Fandos and Katie Benner

articles.headline: At Verizon, a Changing of the Guard as It Pursues 5G
articles.snippet: Hans E. Vestberg, the company’s chief tech officer, will take over from Lowell McAdam. The move signals a renewed focus on internet service and the quest for 5G mobile.
articles.abstract: Hans E. Vestberg, the company’s chief tech officer, will take over from Lowell McAdam. The move signals a renewed focus on internet service and the quest for 5G mobile.
articles.lead_paragraph: The telecom giant Verizon said on Friday that it was installing its head of technology as chief executive. The changing of the guard comes at a time when the wireless industry as a whole is grappling with new technologies and a wave of consolidation.
articles.byline: By Prashant S. Rao and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Trump Shakes Up World Stage in Break With U.S. Allies
articles.snippet: At a moment of tumult over trade and nuclear security, President Trump is making friends with America’s enemies and enemies out of America’s friends.
articles.abstract: At a moment of tumult over trade and nuclear security, President Trump is making friends with America’s enemies and enemies out of America’s friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rarely has President Trump’s role as a disrupter on the world stage been starker. At a moment of tumult over trade and nuclear security, he is shaking up the international order to make friends with America’s enemies and enemies out of America’s friends.

articles.headline: Move Over, China: U.S. Is Again Home to World’s Speediest Supercomputer
articles.snippet: For the past five years, China has had the world’s fastest computer. But as of Friday, Summit, a machine built in the United States, is taking the lead.
articles.abstract: For the past five years, China has had the world’s fastest computer. But as of Friday, Summit, a machine built in the United States, is taking the lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States just won bragging rights in the race to build the world’s speediest supercomputer.
